page.title: 20Types of Housing
page.content: Types of housing in this area are quite varied. The 2 halls in Snelston and Mayfield being built of gritstone and Norbury of brick. Norbury Manor is also brick with an attached medieval hall of stone. There is 1 rectory belonging to the Church which is built in brick, as are the majority of smaller and newer houses and farms. The older buildings particularly in Mayfield are of stone, such as the Mill Cottages and buildings around Mayfield Hall. There are 2 public houses built of brick and in Snelston the Queen Adelaide is also a working farm. There is no council housing in the area but several smallholdings and farm are on tenancies from local estates. This part of the Domesday Project was written and produced by Norbury & Roston Women's Institute.
